none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. W. Walters (), December 7, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. W. Walters (), December 7, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 21 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas

en: A letter from J. W. Walters and colleagues to Louis L. McInnis, a professor of mathematics at Agricultural and Mechanical College in Bryan, requesting a mathematical solution to a livestock breeding problem. The problem asks how many years it would take for a single cow and calf to multiply to one thousand animals, given that all offspring are heifers and breed at two years of age. This document reflects late nineteenth-century agricultural education and the use of practical farming scenarios as mathematical exercises.

body.value:
Kerens Dec 7 1885.

Prof of Mathematics
A & M College, Bryan.
                         Sir,

Please Solve
this problem for us. – Take a
cow & calf in Jan 1880 Suppose
all offspring heifers, and breed at
two years of age in how many
years would they amount to one
thousand allowing nothing in
discount for death &c

Yours &c
J W Waters et. al.

P.S. Send Solution

**Summary of Transcription Process**

Okay, here's the deal. I've got this handwritten letter in front of me, and my job is to get a clean transcription. First thing's first: the image analysis. I'm focusing on those key details.

The top right corner is the usual spot for the date and location. At first, it's a little fuzzy, could be 1888 or 1885, I do a *lot* of comparing the digits. I look at other numbers in the letter for reference, particularly the "0" in 1880, and the "8"s and "5"s. After close examination and some back and forth, I land on "Dec 7 1885" for the date, and "Kerens" is the location. The A&M connection makes sense with the college in Bryan, Texas, and checking online confirms Kerens, TX as a location.

The addressee is clearly "Prof of Mathematics / A & M College, Bryan." Standard salutation is "Sir," indented.

The body of the letter: "Please Solve...". It's a problem, some kind of mathematical puzzle about cows and calves breeding, how many years, what is the impact of death, etc. The language is old-fashioned but clear. I double-check the abbreviations. "&c" means "etcetera", and it's used in the closing.

The signature is "J W Waters et. al.". It has a bit of flourish, and I carefully confirm the letters. I look carefully for the signature, and I confirm the letters "J W Waters". It has a clearly written 'W'. And then I check "et. al.". This is standard for "and others".

There is a PostScript: "P.S. Send Solution". The handwriting is neat.

I then go back and analyze the text closely. I focus on specific words that are a little tricky. I check the town and the date again. I look at the "Mathematics" and "Thousand".

I then think about formatting. I can't use complex styling, like underlining or aligning text using HTML attributes. I make sure to put the line breaks in to mirror the handwritten letter. So the structure is: Date, Address, Salutation, Body, Signature, and Postscript.

I check it again, and I confirm that the formatting is solid. I double check line breaks. I confirm that the spacing makes sense, and I check individual letters. I confirm the date again, and the structure. It all looks right. I am finally confident in the transcription!
